head.title: Improving the Open Circuit Voltage through Surface Oxygen Plasma Treatment and 11.7% Efficient Cu2ZnSnSe4 Solar Cell | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Improving the Open Circuit Voltage through Surface Oxygen Plasma Treatment and 11.7% Efficient Cu2ZnSnSe4 Solar Cell

The photovoltaic performance of Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) solar cells subjected to surface oxygen plasma treatments is investigated. The observed improvements are related to an enhancement of the open circuit voltage VOC, that is, the suppression of the VOC deficit. The VOC monotonically increases with treatment time up to 0.460 V. The origin of this improvement is discussed, and it is concluded that the effectiveness of the surface treatment is not due to oxygen-related alloying but instead to the homogeneous oxidation and removal of the oxidized CZTSe surface layer. The surface oxygen content increases with surface treatment time, although surface oxides are fully removed after ammonia treatment, which is conducted in a similar manner to CdS buffer deposition. The reduction of surface recombination is confirmed by time-resolved photoluminescence measurements, and the minority carrier lifetime deduced using the fast decay component increases with increasing treatment time. The relationship between photovoltaic properties and lifetime is clearly demonstrated. The best-performing CZTSe solar cell obtained using surface oxygen treatment demonstrates a conversion efficiency of 11.7%, which is higher than those of previous reports on CZTSe cells.

div.p:
The photovoltaic performance of Cu
2
ZnSnSe
4
(CZTSe) solar cells subjected to surface oxygen plasma treatments is investigated. The observed improvements are related to an enhancement of the open circuit voltage
V
OC
, that is, the suppression of the
V
OC
deficit. The
V
OC
monotonically increases with treatment time up to 0.460 V. The origin of this improvement is discussed, and it is concluded that the effectiveness of the surface treatment is not due to oxygen-related alloying but instead to the homogeneous oxidation and removal of the oxidized CZTSe surface layer. The surface oxygen content increases with surface treatment time, although surface oxides are fully removed after ammonia treatment, which is conducted in a similar manner to CdS buffer deposition. The reduction of surface recombination is confirmed by time-resolved photoluminescence measurements, and the minority carrier lifetime deduced using the fast decay component increases with increasing treatment time. The relationship between photovoltaic properties and lifetime is clearly demonstrated. The best-performing CZTSe solar cell obtained using surface oxygen treatment demonstrates a conversion efficiency of 11.7%, which is higher than those of previous reports on CZTSe cells.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In order to achieve the goals of the Paris Agreement and Sustainable Development Goals, terawatt-scale mass production of solar cells is anticipated by 2030.
(1)
Terawatt-scale photovoltaic (PV) production corresponds to tens of times the current production and is a very challenging target. Therefore, the use of solar cells that employ earth-abundant materials is crucial in order to meet the demands of terawatt-scale production in terms of both cost and resources. Cu
2
ZnSn(S,Se)
4
(CZTSSe)-based solar cells are good candidates to meet this demand because CZTSSe is composed of earth-abundant materials and the commercialized technologies used for Cu(In,Ga)Se
2
(CIGS) and CdTe solar cells can be employed. CZTSSe is a I
2
âIIâIVâVI
4
compound semiconductor and a derivative of IâIIIâVI
2
CIGS. There has been a great deal of technological development related to CIGS solar cells that may be applied to CZTSSe solar cells. However, the PV performance of CZTSSe-based cells is still low compared to that of CIGS solar cells; their certified highest conversion efficiency of 12.6%
(2)
is much lower than that of 23.35% for CIGS solar cells,
(3)
and many researchers are trying to bridge this gap. This is mainly because CZTSSe is a quaternary compound that contains various defects that are difficult to control, and the technologies related to defect control are not fully developed compared to those for the commercialized chalcogenide CIGS and CdTe solar cells.
(4)
The most serious issue related to CZTSSe-based solar cells is their large open circuit voltage (
V
OC
deficit) compared to the band gap energy.
(4,5)
The
V
OC
deficits of GaAs,Â Si, CIGS, and CdTe solar cells are reported to be â¼0.3, â¼0.4, â¼0.4, and â¼0.6 V, respectively.
(6)
The
V
OC
deficit of CZTSe-based solar cell must be reduced to a level comparable to that of CIGS cells in order to replace them.

In general, the fundamental mechanism that determines
V
OC
is a recombination process; the lower the recombination rate in the solar cell, the higher the
V
OC
.
(7)
The structure of the CZTSSe-based solar cell is similar to that of CIGS solar cells except for the absorber. Therefore, the
V
OC
is considered to be limited by the recombination in the bulk and/or at the interface of the CZTSSe.
(5)
There are several papers related to improvements of kesterite-based cells from the perspective of the quality of the bulk or/and the surface. In terms of improving bulk quality, alloying and doping are typical techniques, for example, Ge alloying,
(8)
Ge doping,
(9,10)
Li alloying,
(11)
compositional grading,
(12â14)
and also alkaline element doping.
(11,15â21)
Various types of surface treatment and corresponding improvements were also reported.
(22â25)
However, the relationships between photovoltaic properties and basic limiting properties such as minority carrier lifetime, diffusion length, and mobility are not clearly understood. This is a large barrier to improving the conversion efficiency of kesterite-based cells and should be investigated further.

Time-resolved photoluminescence (TRPL) is a powerful tool for evaluating the quality of materials and devices in terms of the carrier lifetime and decay mechanism. These have been reported and discussed in both theoretical and experimental terms
(26,27)
and also in the case of kesterite materials and devices.
(15,18,28â33)
In our previous paper,
(18)
we reported improvements of CZTSe bulk properties that were obtained using Na doping. The minority carrier lifetime estimated using TRPL measurements, which is related to CZTSe bulk recombination and a slow decay component, increased from 2 to 15 ns. However, the Na doping did not induce any improvement in the
V
OC
despite the improvement of the bulk lifetime. Moreover, one paper reported no correlation between the measured PL decay times and photovoltaic properties over a wide range of efficiency (1â12%) and
V
OC
.
(33)
These results imply that the recombination process in kesterite is limited not only by the bulk region but also by other recombination mechanisms. In this study, we use a surface treatment in order to increase the
V
OC
of CZTSe cells and discuss the origins of the resulting improvements and limitations.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
CZTSe thin films were grown by the coevaporation method using molecular beam epitaxy equipment, and the films were thermally treated in a tube furnace under Se and SnSe atmospheres. Surface treatment was carried out using oxygen plasma ashing equipment before CdS deposition. The equipment is originally designed for ashing residuals of photoresists. The oxygen plasma treatments were conducted under an oxygen flow of 200 sccm maintaining a pressure of 100 Pa. The stage is 160 mm in diameter, and an RF power of 200 W was applied. KCN treatment was also used, and then CdS deposition was continuously conducted by chemical bath deposition. The CZTSe solar cells were fabricated based on a CIGS solar cell except for the absorbers, ZnO:Al (350 nm)/i-ZnO (50 nm)/CdS (50 nm)/CZTSe (1.8 Î¼m)/Mo/soda lime glass. ZnO:Al and i-ZnO layers were deposited using the sputtering method. The other structure was used for obtaining the best-performing cell, namely, ZnO:Al (350 nm)/i-ZnO (30 nm)/CdS (30 nm)/CZTSe (1.8 Î¼m)/Mo/soda lime glass. The thickness of the CdS layer was 30 nm, and the i-ZnO layer was deposited using atomic layer deposition (Oxford FlexAL). The currentâvoltage measurements were conducted under simulated AM 1.5G (100 mW/cm
2
) illumination. A scribed designated area (not active area) of 0.522 cm
2
was used in this study. Antireflection coating was not used except for the best-performing cell. Time-resolved photoluminescence (TRPL) measurements were conducted on CZTSe device structures using a Hamamatsu Photonics C12132 NIR TRPL system with the second harmonic of an yttriumâaluminumâgarnet laser (532 nm). The repetition frequency, pulse length, and power of the laser were 15 kHz, <1.2 ns, and 1.4 mW, respectively. The surface composition of CZTSe was evaluated by electron probe microanalysis measurements (Shimadzu EPMA-1720) with an acceleration voltage of 5 kV, which corresponds to an evaluation depth of â¼100 nm. The average CZTSe composition was evaluated by X-ray fluorescence measurements (Shimadzu EDX-720). The surface morphology and contrast were evaluated by scanning electron microscopy (Hitachi S-4800), and the compositions were evaluated at the same time using electron dispersive X-ray spectrometry (Horiba EMAX) with the SEM equipment.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In a previous study,
(18)
the slow component (â¼10 ns) in TRPL measurements of CZTSe was concluded to be a recombination in the bulk region, although the origin of the fast decay components was unclear. In general, the PL decay recombination includes various types of recombination processes, such as radiative and nonradiative recombination, surface recombination, and charge separation. In the same paper,
(18)
the CIGS cell showed a clear single exponential decay for a similar sample structure and a similar TRPL setup including the excitation power density. Therefore, it was speculated that the fast components were due to the surface recombination. In this study, the relationship between fast decay components and surface treatments was first investigated.

The minority carrier lifetimes estimated using TRPL were improved by oxygen plasma surface treatment as shown in
Figure
1
. The results described in
Figure
1
a show a lifetime that monotonically improved from 1.1 to 2.1 ns with increasing treatment time from 0 to 20 min. It was concluded that the decay components originated from the surface recombination because they were improved by the surface treatment. The lifetimes were estimated by exponential decay curves with three components and an instrument response function (IRF) using the DecayFit software
(34)
as shown in
Figure
1
b. The decay was fitted in terms of three components: fast, middle, and slow, which correspond to less than 1 ns, 1â2 ns, and â¼10 ns, respectively. Only the middle decay components (1â2 ns) are characterized in this study. This is because the slow decay components were very weak and the uncertainty on these was very high. There was also no observed improvement in the slow decay components, which originates from bulk recombination. This is consistent with the fact that the surface treatment affected the surface recombination, not the bulk recombination.
Figure
1
c shows the PL decay curve for an optimized sample fabricated in this study. Surface oxygen plasma treatment and also Na doping were conducted, a lifetime Ï
b
of 13 ns was obtained, and the properties of this sample are discussed in the following section. The fast decay components were also observed as shown in
Figure
1
; however, the origin of the recombination is currently unclear, and further investigations are necessary.

div.p: Figure 1. Photoluminescence (PL) decay curves for the surface-treated CZTSe cell as a function of treatment time (a), PL decay curves and fitting curves with and without the surface treatment (b), and PL decay curve and fitting curve for the best-performing CZTSe cell (c). A corresponding bulk related lifetime of 13 ns was obtained for the best-performing CZTSe cell. The time scale of panel (c) differs from those of panels (a) and (b).

div.h3: Oxidation and Removal through Surface Treatment
div.div:
The oxidation of the CZTSe surface through the oxygen plasma treatment was characterized by electron probe microanalysis (EPMA) with an acceleration of 5 kV, which corresponds to an evaluation depth of â¼100 nm.
Figure
2
shows the oxygen composition of oxygen plasma treated samples before and after being dipped in aqueous ammonia with the same ammonia concentration (â¼2 mol/L) as was used for chemical bath deposition of the CdS buffer layer. As shown in
Figure
2
, the oxygen composition monotonically increased with the treatment time, which means that the oxygen originates from oxides and the oxidation monotonically proceeded from the surface. However, all the oxygen was removed after aqueous ammonia dipping despite the initial oxygen concentration.

div.p: Figure 2. Changes of oxygen composition with oxygen plasma surface treatment of CZTSe before and after aqueous ammonia treatment. There are three data sets for each treatment and process time.

div.div:
The differences of standard Gibbs free energies of formation at 25 Â°C between Cu
2
Se and Cu
2
O, ZnSe and ZnO, and SnSe and SnO are â74.6, â163.2, and â156.0 kJ/mol, respectively.
(35)
Therefore, if Cu
2
Se, ZnSe, and SnSe are formed at the surface, these could be converted to oxides. In fact, the selenides are expected to be easily oxidized under a strong oxidizing environment such as oxygen plasma. Cu
2
ZnSnO
4
(CZTO) exhibits a smaller formation energy than CZTSe with an energy difference of â542.7 kJ/mol,
(36)
which corresponds to the energy difference of the standard Gibbs free energy of formation at 0 K between the two compounds. Therefore, CZTSe is also expected to be converted into CZTO. Moreover, the chalcogenide compounds are known to exhibit higher solubilities and greater solubility products in the same cation compounds, following the order of tellurides, selenides, and sulfides.
(37)
A similar order is expected in the case of oxides. The solubility products of oxides (selenides), namely, Cu
2
O (Cu
2
Se), ZnO (ZnSe), and SnO (SnSe), are 4 Ã 10
â30
(2 Ã 10
â61
), 2 Ã 10
â17
(4 Ã 10
â30
), and 6 Ã 10
â27
(4 Ã 10
â39
), respectively.
(38)
Furthermore, the oxidized-CZTSe Cu
2
ZnSnO
4
(CZTO) is expected to have a greater solubility product compared to that of CZTSe. Zn and Cu ions in aqueous ammonia form ammonia complexes of [Zn(NH
3
)
4
]
2+
and [Cu(NH
3
)
2
]
2+
, respectively, and no Sn ammonia complex is formed in aqueous ammonia.
(39)
Therefore, ZnO is the most soluble in water, and if ZnO is formed, this is preferentially removed.

div.h3: Morphology Change by Oxidation and Removal
div.div:
Spatially homogeneous oxidation caused by the surface oxygen plasma treatment and the homogeneous removal of oxides were observed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM).
Figure
3
shows the SEM images without either surface or aqueous ammonia treatments (panel (a)), with surface treatment and without aqueous ammonia treatment (panel (b)), with both surface and aqueous ammonia treatment (panel (c)), and without surface treatment but with aqueous ammonia treatment (the control treatment) (panel (d)). As shown in
Figure
3
a, there are relatively dark and light regions in the image, and the Zn composition in the light region was higher than that in the dark region as evaluated by energy dispersive X-ray spectrometry with the SEM equipment. The lighter region with an excess Zn composition is also observed in CZTSe grown using a ZnSe/Cu
2
SnSe
3
/ZnSe precursor with a thick ZnSe top layer. ZnSe and the Zn-rich region of CZTSe both exhibit light areas in the SEM.
(40)
However, this contrast disappeared after surface treatment as shown in
Figure
3
b, where the homogeneity of the contrast was almost identical for each treatment time (see the
Supporting Information
). This means that the surface was fully and homogeneously oxidized even after 1 min of treatment despite fluctuation of the Zn composition.

div.p: Figure 3. SEM images of the CZTSe surface without either surface treatment or aqueous ammonia treatment (a), with the surface treatment and without aqueous ammonia treatment (b), with both the surface treatment and aqueous ammonia treatment (c), and without surface treatment and with aqueous ammonia treatment (control sample) (d).

div.div:
The effect on the contrast of the Zn composition was also apparent after aqueous ammonia treatment as shown in
Figure
3
c. Here, the morphology and contrast, which corresponds to the Zn compositional distribution, were almost identical to those before oxidation that are shown in
Figure
3
a. These results suggest that the surface was homogeneously oxidized both in-plane and perpendicular to the surface and the oxide layer was fully removed by the aqueous ammonia. The CZTSe itself, including its relatively Zn-rich and Zn-poor regions, is therefore considered to be oxidized and removed homogeneously, as opposed to the preferential oxidation and removal of secondary phases such as Cu
2
Se, ZnSe, and SnSe. Although the secondary phases were not dominantly formed at the CZTSe surface, they were also expected to be removed at the same time as the removal of the oxidized CZTSe layer. Removal of the secondary phases was attributed to the suppression of the surface recombination.
Figure
3
d shows an SEM image of the control sample, which is very similar to that of
Figure
3
c in terms of morphology and contrast.

div.h3: Effect of Surface Treatment on Photovoltaic Properties
div.div:
The photovoltaic properties were improved by the surface oxygen plasma treatment as shown in
Figure
4
. Here,
J
â
V
curves for surface-treated CZTSe solar cells are shown as a function of treatment time. It was found that the conversion efficiency monotonically increased from 6.6 to 9.2% with increasing treatment time and the
V
OC
monotonically increased from 0.416 to 0.460 V as shown in
Table
1
. The current density (
J
SC
) slightly increased. The
V
OC
reached a highest value of 0.460 V and a lowest
V
OC
deficit (
E
g
/
q
â
V
OC
) of 0.62 V with a band gap energy of 1.08 eV measured at the inflection point of the EQE spectrum. The
V
OC
deficit was comparable to that of the CZTSSe champion cell at 0.617 V.
(2)
The band gap energies evaluated via EQE varied from 1.07 to 1.08 eV with all treatments, which are larger than that of the best-performing cell; they are discussed based on the EQE spectra below. As mentioned earlier, no relationship between PV properties and lifetime has been previously reported. However, in the present study, a positive relationship between PV properties and lifetime was clearly observed.

div.p:
Figure 4.
J
â
V
curves for the CZTSe cells as a function of surface treatment time from 0 to 30 min.

div.div: Table 1. PV Properties of CZTSe Cells with Various Surface Treatment Times

The suppression of surface recombination was also observed using EQE measurements as shown in
Figure
5
. It was found that EQE improved within the shorter wavelength region of the CZTSe absorption spectrum (Î» > 540 nm). This implies that the recombination loss near the top surface of CZTSe was reduced by the CZTSe surface treatment. Moreover, EQE was also improved in the CdS absorption region (400â540 nm), which might be due to suppression of CdS/CZTSe interface recombination as demonstrated for the CdS/CIGS interface.
(41)
The poor EQE of CZTSe cells with a rapid degradation in the longer wavelength region (Î» > 600 nm) is due to the short collection length
L
c
of CZTSe, which was estimated using the e-ARC method.
(42)
Figure
6
shows a simulation of the EQE spectrum for a sample after a 30 min treatment, and the collection length was estimated to be 470 nm. This simulation result implies that surface recombination still occurs because there is a relatively large deviation between the calculated and experimental EQE spectra in the short-wavelength region of CZTSe absorption, while the case without treatment shows a greater deviation. This deviation might indicate the extent of surface and near surface recombination, although more detailed investigations into this relationship are necessary. It is of note that the band edges were almost identical from 1.07 to 1.08 eV according to the EQE spectra as shown in
Figure
5
. Therefore, it might be concluded that the oxygen-incorporated CZTSe is not formed after aqueous ammonia treatment, which is consistent with the removal of the homogeneous oxidized layer as shown in
Figure
2
. The effect of alloying with oxygen is negligible according to the EPMA and EQE results; however, the top surface of CZTSe might be slightly oxidized, which might improve the
V
OC
.

div.p: Figure 5. EQE spectra of CZTSe cells as a function of surface treatment time from 0 to 30 min.
Figure 6. EQE simulation using the e-ARC method for the surface-treated and best-performing CZTSe cell.

div.div:
The
J
â
V
curve for the best-performing CZTSe cell with surface treatment is shown in
Figure
7
with a conversion efficiency of 11.7%. The
V
OC
,
J
SC
, and FF were 0.423 V, 41.7 mA/cm
2
, and 0.666, respectively. In this optimal cell, 10 min of surface treatment was used, and a thinner CdS buffer of 30 nm was used to improve the
J
SC
, although a lower
V
OC
was obtained for the thinner CdS. In order to protect the CdS/CZTSe heterointerface from sputtering damage to the thinner CdS layer, intrinsic ZnO was applied using atomic layer deposition (ALD). Moreover, 10 nm NaF was deposited before thermal treatment to improve the CZTSe bulk properties through Na incorporation, and MgF
2
was also used for the antireflection layer. The slightly lower
V
OC
of the best-performing cell compared to that indicated in
Figure
4
might be due to the thinner CdS and the NaF layers, although this must be investigated further. We observed lowering of the
V
OC
for the thinner CdS and found that it was possible to suppress the degradation of
V
OC
using i-ZnO deposited via ALD. However, the relationships on PV properties between CdS layer thicknesses, the usage of ALD of ZnO, and the alkaline incorporation are not sufficiently investigated and require extensive investigations. The device parameters of the cell are compared with those reported for the CZTSe champion cell in
Table
2
.
(43)
The parameters of these two cells were almost identical; for example, the efficiency of the current cell (champion cell) was 11.7% (11.6%), the
V
OC
values were both 0.423 V, and the ideality factor was almost the same at 1.56 (1.57). It is notable that the
J
SC
values calculated from EQE of the best-performing cell and the cell with the 30 min treatment shown in
Figure
6
were 39.6 and 30.5 mA/cm
2
, respectively, which are slightly smaller than those obtained via
J
â
V
measurements. The difference is considered to be mainly because of dc measurements in EQE, and the measured
J
SC
is acceptable because the
J
SC
for the best-performing cell was certified to be 40.91 mA/cm
2
by Japan Electrical Safety & Environment Technology Laboratories (JET). The certified cell performance of efficiency,
V
OC
, and FF were 11.2%, 0.4218 V, and 0.647, respectively (see the
Supporting Information
). Degradation in the efficiency was also confirmed via in-house measurement, and the efficiency measured in-house just before the JET measurement was 11.1%. Degradation is sometimes observed after cell fabrication.

div.p:
Figure 7.
J
â
V
curve for the best-performing CZTSe cell with surface treatment and Na incorporation.

div.div: Table 2. Comparison of Device Parameters of the Best-Performing CZTSe Cell and the Reported Champion CZTSe Cell

div.p:
ref
(2)
.

div.div:
Figure
6
also shows the EQE spectrum for the best-performing cell with the simulated spectrum, and the band gap energy was estimated to be 1.00 eV at the inflection point of the EQE spectrum. Furthermore, it was found that a much larger collection length
L
c
of 2.0 Î¼m was obtained compared to a length of 0.47 Î¼m obtained without the surface treatment. The relatively lower
V
OC
compared to that of the samples presented in
Table
1

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The
V
OC
deficit of a CZTSe solar cell has been decreased up to 0.540 V through surface oxygen plasma treatment. A clean surface with low recombination was obtained by homogeneous oxidation and removal of the oxidized layer. A relationship between the PV properties and PL lifetime was clearly observed, and
V
OC
was found to linearly increase with increasing lifetime, an effect that is related to surface recombination. A conversion efficiency of 11.7% was obtained for the CZTSe solar cell using this surface treatment and Na incorporation, which provides the highest reported efficiency in the case of CZTSe cells. The increased
V
OC
of the CZTSe cells described in this study implies that these kesterite-based cells could be a viable option to replace CIGS cells in the future.

A review. Intense research has been carried out in the past few years to improve efficiencies and understand limitations in kesterite-based solar cells. Despite notable efforts to det. and list the different failure modes affecting the photovoltaic properties of these devices, very few works have tried to quantify and classify the effects of these failure modes. An exhaustive literature review has 1st been conducted to det. the different causes leading to limited efficiencies in kesterite devices, with an addnl. focus on Cd-free and crit. raw material-free devices. Second, an original approach has been employed to quantify the impact of these failure modes on solar cells, based on the evaluation of feedback from 18 scientific experts working on kesterite technol. The result of this survey is analyzed, which allows one to det. what should be the research priority for the community to improve efficiencies and drive kesterite technol. to the market.

We demonstrate the improved efficiency of a Cu2Zn(Sn1-xGex)Se4 (CZTGSe) thin-film solar cell with a conversion efficiency of 12.3%; this cell exhibits a greatly improved open-circuit voltage (VOC) deficit of 0.583V and a fill factor (FF) of 0.73 compared with previously reported CZTGSe cells. The VOC deficit was found to be improved through a reduced band tailing via the control of the Ge/(Sn + Se) ratio. In addn., the high FF was mainly induced by a reduced carrier recombination at the absorber/buffer interface and/or in the space charge region, whereas parasitic resistive effects on FF were very small.

A band-gap-graded CZTSSe solar cell with 12.3% efficiency
Yang, Kee-Jeong; Son, Dae-Ho; Sung, Shi-Joon; Sim, Jun-Hyoung; Kim, Young-Ill; Park, Si-Nae; Jeon, Dong-Hwan; Kim, JungSik; Hwang, Dae-Kue; Jeon, Chan-Wook; Nam, Dahyun; Cheong, Hyeonsik; Kang, Jin-Kyu; Kim, Dae-Hwan

Although Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe) has attracted attention as an alternative to CuInGaSe2 (CIGS) as an absorber material in solar cells, its low efficiency is a serious shortcoming preventing its commercialization. To realize a high-efficiency CZTSSe solar cell, improved grain crystallinity, inhibited secondary-phase formation, controlled defect generation, adequate Na content, and band gap grading are required in the absorber layer. Few studies have focused specifically on band gap grading. In this study, a method of using SeS2, a new potential chalcogenization source material, to control the S and Se contents in a CZTSSe absorber and its effects were investigated. Using an appropriate SeS2/Se wt. ratio, band gap grading was realized within the depletion region. By increasing the value of VOC through band gap grading in the depletion region, a record VOC deficit of 0.576 V was achieved. Furthermore, the possibility of enhancing JSC through the formation of a type-inverted n-type phase at the absorber surface in response to an appropriate alignment of the conduction-band min. energy level and the Fermi energy pinning level is discussed. By introducing the chalcogenization source material SeS2 during the annealing process, CZTSSe solar cells with a max. efficiency of 12.3% were obtained.

The effect of the band-gap profile on the performance of Cu2ZnSn(Sx,Se1-x)4 (CZTSSe) solar cells was investigated using a solar cell capacitance simulator (SCAPS) device simulation program. The band gap of CZTSSe is tunable from 1.0 to 1.5 eV by changing the S/(S + Se) ratio. Currently, the evolution of the electron affinity (Î§) of CZTSSe at various band gaps has not been clarified yet, although two models with different Î§ values at various band gaps of CZTSSe have been proposed. We simulated solar cell performance using these two models and the differential rates of efficiency were compared between them. As a result, we were able to design the optimum band-gap profile using both models. Meanwhile, the characteristics of a solar cell with various optical absorption coeffs. and defect densities of the CZTSSe absorber were simulated. The superiority of the graded band-gap profile was demonstrated by comparing the cell performances with and without a grading profile structure.

Alkali doping strategies for flexible and light-weight Cu2ZnSnSe4 solar cells
Lopez-Marino, Simon; Sanchez, Yudania; Espindola-Rodriguez, Moises; Alcobe, Xavier; Xie, Haibing; Neuschitzer, Markus; Becerril, Ignacio; Giraldo, Sergio; Dimitrievska, Mirjana; Placidi, Marcel; Fourdrinier, Lionel; Izquierdo-Roca, Victor; Perez-Rodriguez, Alejandro; Saucedo, Edgardo

In this work we report on the effect of alkali doping via Na and/or K introduction into flexible and light-wt. Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) solar cells obtained using a sequential process based on the sputtering of metallic stacks and further reactive annealing. Different thicknesses of Cr diffusion barriers and 50 Î¼m thick ferritic steel substrates were used. We compare different doping methods: Na-doped Mo targets (MoNa), SLG underneath the flexible substrates, NaF and KF pre-absorber synthesis evapn. (PAS) and post-deposition evapn. (PDT). Addnl., we report on the importance of the Cr barrier and back contact modification to improve solar cell performance. A remarkable enhancement in the absorber grain size and surface morphol. occurred esp. when using Na via MoNa and PAS. Nevertheless, preliminary expts. led to better results for MoNa doping due to a higher Na content confirmed by TOF-SIMS. K doping via PAS also showed promising results. An increase in the efficiency of solar cells from 2.2% to 4.3% was possible when using a MoNa layer sandwiched between regular Mo layers. The improvement is mainly related to a higher VOC and FF. After performing a detailed Cr and back contact optimization, a record value of 6.1% for flexible CZTSe solar cells was recently obtained using MoNa and a new surface Ge doping.

Impact of Na Dynamics at the Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4/CdS Interface During Post Low Temperature Treatment of Absorbers
Xie, Haibing; Lopez-Marino, Simon; Olar, Tetiana; Sanchez, Yudania; Neuschitzer, Markus; Oliva, Florian; Giraldo, Sergio; Izquierdo-Roca, Victor; Lauermann, Iver; Perez-Rodriguez, Alejandro; Saucedo, Edgardo

(

American Chemical Society

Cu2SnZn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe) solar cells based on earth abundant and nontoxic elements currently achieve efficiencies exceeding 12%. It has been reported that, to obtain high efficiency devices, a post thermal treatment of absorbers or devices at temps. ranging between 150 and 400 Â°C (post low temp. treatment, PLTT) is advisable. Recent findings point toward a beneficial passivation of grain boundaries with SnOx or Cu-depleted surface and grain boundaries during the PLTT process, but no investigation regarding alkali doping is available, even though alkali dynamics, esp. Na, are systematically reported to be crucial within the field. In this work, CZTSSe absorbers were subjected to the PLTT process under different temps., and solar cells were completed. We found surprisingly behavior in which efficiency decreased to nearly 0% at 200 Â°C during the PLTT process, being recovered or even improved at temps. above 300 Â°C. This unusual behavior correlates well with the Na dynamics in the devices, esp. with the in-depth distribution of Na in the active CZTSSe/CdS interface region, indicating the key importance of Na spatial distribution on device properties. We present an innovative model for Na dynamics supported by theor. calcns. and addnl. specially designed expts. to explain this behavior. After optimization of the PLTT process, a Se-rich CZTSSe solar cell with 8.3% efficiency was achieved.

The effect of Na incorporation in Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) solar cells grown by the coevaporation method was investigated via photoluminescence (PL) and time-resolved PL (TRPL) measurements as well as photovoltaic properties. The TRPL decay curves showed a monotonic increase in CZTSe lifetime from 2 to 15 ns with increasing Na incorporation, which corresponds to the increase in the correction length estd. by quantum efficiency measurements. The TRPL decay curves included two decay components, fast and slow, which were discussed and concluded as originating from the recombination at the surface and bulk of CZTSe, resp., which is also supported by TPRL measurements with various excitation wavelengths. The lifetime of CZTSe is limited by the surface-related nonradiative recombination compared to Cu(In,Ga)Se2 devices which are fabricated with the same device structure except for the absorber, and at present, it is concluded that the surface recombination of the CZTSe limits the cell performance. In addn. to the above investigations, the relationship between the CZTSe bulk lifetime and carrier concn. is discussed; deep nonradiative recombination centers in the CZTSe bulk were found to decrease by one order of magnitude with Na incorporation. The Na incorporation primarily resulted in improvement in the short circuit c.d. and fill factor and not in the open circuit voltage, and the results are discussed. The best performing CZTSe solar cell with Na incorporation showed a conversion efficiency of 9.57%. (c) 2017 American Institute of Physics.

It is well established that the addn. of sodium (Na) to chalcopyrite or kesterite based solar cells markedly increases the solar cell performance. In this work, we explore the effect of Na and other alkali metals like potassium (K), rubidium, cesium and lithium (Li) - on pure selenide Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) solar cells. We demonstrate the deposition of alkali metals using spin coating on e-beam evapd. metal precursors. The stack of metal precursors with alkali layer was then selenized at high temps. to obtain a good quality CZTSe absorber. The diffusion of alkali metals into the absorber layer was confirmed using glow discharge optical emission spectroscopy. Samples doped with Na or K have shown improvement in the open circuit voltage. A max. power conversion efficiency of 8.3% (without anti-reflection coating) and a top open circuit voltage 430 mV was achieved for combination of K and Na. Amongst the rest of alkali metals, Li looks the most promising dopant as far as optoelectronic properties are concerned.

Potassium (K) post-treatment on CIGSSe has been shown to yield the highest efficiency reported to date. However, very little is known on the effect of K doping in CZTSSe and the mechanism behind the efficiency improvement. Here we reveal the mechanism by which K enhances the charge sepn. in CZTSSe. We show that K accumulates at the CdS/CZTSSe, passivating the recombination at the front interface and improving carrier collection. K is also found to accumulate at the CZTSSe/Mo interface and facilitates the diffusion of Cd into the absorber which affects the morphol. and grain growth of CZTSSe. As revealed by the C-V, external quantum efficiency, and color J-V test, K doping significantly increases the carrier d., improves carrier collection, and passivates the front interface and grain boundaries, leading to the enhancement of Voc and Jsc. The av. power conversion efficiency has been promoted from 5% to above 7%, and the best 7.78% efficiency has been achieved for the 1.5 mol % K-doped CZTSSe device. This work offers some new insights into the K doping effects on CZTSSe via soln.-based approach and demonstrates the potential of facile control of K doping for further improvement of CZTSSe thin film solar cells.

Sulfide kesterite Cu2ZnSnS4 provides an attractive low-cost, environmentally benign and stable photovoltaic material, yet the record power conversion efficiency for such solar cells has been stagnant at around 9% for years. Severe non-radiative recombination within the heterojunction region is a major cause limiting voltage output and overall performance. Here we report a certified 11% efficiency Cu2ZnSnS4 solar cell with a high 730 mV open-circuit voltage using heat treatment to reduce heterojunction recombination. This heat treatment facilitates elemental inter-diffusion, directly inducing Cd atoms to occupy Zn or Cu lattice sites, and promotes Na accumulation accompanied by local Cu deficiency within the heterojunction region. Consequently, new phases are formed near the hetero-interface and more favorable conduction band alignment is obtained, contributing to reduced non-radiative recombination. Using this approach, we also demonstrate a certified centimetre-scale (1.11 cm2) 10% efficiency Cu2ZnSnS4 photovoltaic device; the first kesterite cell (including selenium-contg.) of std. centimetre-size to exceed 10%.

Cu2ZnSnSe4 kesterite-type compds. are some of the most promising materials for low-cost thin-film photovoltaics. However, the synthesis of absorbers for high-performing devices is still a complex issue. So far, the best devices rely on absorbers grown in a Zn-rich and Cu-poor environment. These off-stoichiometric conditions favor the presence of a ZnSe secondary phase, which has been proved to be highly detrimental for device performance. Therefore, an effective method for the selective removal of this phase is important. Previous attempts to remove this phase by using acidic etching or highly toxic org. compds. have been reported but so far with moderate impact on device performance. Herein, a new oxidizing route to ensure efficient removal of ZnSe is presented based on treatment with a mixt. of an oxidizing agent and a mineral acid followed by treatment in an aq. Na2S soln. Three different oxidizing agents were tested: H2O2, KMnO4, and K2Cr2O7, combined with different concns. of H2SO4. With all of these agents Se2- from the ZnSe surface phase is selectively oxidized to Se0, forming an elemental Se phase, which is removed with the subsequent etching in Na2S. Using KMnO4 in a H2SO4-based medium, a large improvement on the conversion efficiency of the devices is obsd., related to an improvement of all the optoelectronic parameters of the cells. Improvement of short-circuit c.d. (Jsc) and series resistance is directly related to the selective etching of the ZnSe surface phase, which has a demonstrated current-blocking effect. In addn., a significant improvement of open-circuit voltage (Voc), shunt resistance (Rsh), and fill factor (FF) are attributed to a passivation effect of the kesterite absorber surface resulting from the chem. processes, an effect that likely leads to a redn. of nonradiative-recombination states d. and a subsequent improvement of the p-n junction.

Time-resolved luminescence (TRL) is a nondestructive, noninvasive, and contactless characterization method. The authors studied TRL decay on semiconductor layers and thin film homostructures after a steady state illumination by simulation with Synopsys TCAD and by anal. approx. soln. of the appropriate equations. First, the luminescence decay time in general is the minority carrier lifetime only for a homogeneous and time-independent carrier lifetime. Then, the authors study the influence of photon recycling, injection level, charge carrier diffusion, defects in the bulk and at the surfaces, as well as space charge on the TRL decay sep. by quasi 1-dimensional simulations of semiconductor layers and semiconductor homostructures. The authors further study the influence of sample nonhomogeneity as may be found in polycryst. semiconductors. Carrier lifetime can be extd. from the TRL transients and the samples can be characterized by excitation dependent measurements in the open circuit case. The authors can explain some effects found in luminescence expts., like a decrease of the decay time with an increasing excitation, a max. in the decay time due to satd. bulk-defects and curved luminescence transients due to high injections or sample inhomogeneities. Also, the authors are focussing on the question, how single layers within a semiconductor stack can be characterized. (c) 2014 American Institute of Physics.

In this work, the benefits of Ag-alloying in kesterite solar cells are explored in terms of tunable band gap, improved grain growth, improved minority carrier lifetime, reduced defect formation, and reduced potential fluctuations for (Ag,Cu)2ZnSnSe4 (ACZTSe) absorbers relative to Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe). The enhanced optoelectronic properties are shown to scale here with the degree of Ag-alloying in ACZTSe. The impacts of these effects on device performance are discussed, with improvement in av. device performance/open-circuit voltage reported for ACZTSe (5%-Ag) absorbers relative to CZTSe absorbers with similar band gap. These initial results are promising for the Ag-alloyed ACZTSe material system as VOC limitations are the primary cause of poor device performance in kesterite solar cells, and cation substitution presents a unique method to tune the defect properties of kesterite absorbers. Herein, nanoparticle synthesis and large-grain ACZTSe absorber formation is described followed by material and optoelectronic characterization. Addnl., RTP processing is presented to achieve fully selenized large-grain chalcogenide absorbers from sulfide nanocrystal inks.

It is a challenge to fabricate high quality Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) film with low Cu content (Cu/(Zn + Sn) < 0.8). In this work, the growth mechanisms of CZTSe films under different Se vapor compn. are investigated by DC-sputtering and a postselenization approach. The compn. of Se vapor has important effect on the compactability of the films and the diffusion of elements in the CZTSe films. By adjusting the compn. of Se vapor during the selenization process, an optimized two step selenization process is proposed and highly crystd. CZTSe film with low Cu content (Cu/(Zn + Sn) = 0.75) is obtained. Further study of the effect of Cu content on the morphol. and photovoltaic performance of the corresponding CZTSe solar cells has shown that the roughness of the CZTSe absorber film increases when Cu content decreases. As a consequence, the reflection loss of CZTSe solar cells reduces dramatically and the short circuit c.d. of the cells improve from 34.7 mA/cm2 for Cu/(Zn + Sn) = 0.88 to 38.5 mA/cm2 for Cu/(Zn + Sn) = 0.75. In addn., the CZTSe solar cells with low Cu content show longer minority carrier lifetime and higher open circuit voltage than the high Cu content devices. A champion performance CZTSe solar cell with 10.4% efficiency is fabricated with Cu/(Zn + Sn) = 0.75 in the CZTSe film without antireflection coating.

DecayFit.
www.fluortools.com
The measured decay curves inclue effect of finite instrument reponse, which limit the time resolution in the meaurement, and it is called as instruments response function (IRF). The IRF is actually measuremed by a reference materilal with very fact decay comared to the instrument response. The real decay curve can be evaluated by decomvolution of the measured curve using IRF. The decomvolution and following fitting were conducted by the DecayFit software.

Cu2ZnSnSxO4-x and Cu2ZnSnSxSe4-x: First principles simulations of optimal alloy configurations and their energies
Dun, Chaochao; Holzwarth, N. A. W.; Li, Yuan; Huang, Wenxiao; Carroll, David L.
Journal of Applied Physics (Melville, NY, United States)
(
2014
),
115
(
19
),
193513/1-193513/12
CODEN:
JAPIAU
; ISSN:
0021-8979
.
(
American Institute of Physics
)
With the aim of exploring oxidn. and selenization of the photovoltaic material Cu2ZnSnS4, we used first principles methods to study the structure and stability of Cu2ZnSnSxO4-x and Cu2ZnSnSxSe4-x alloys for 0 â¤ x â¤ 4. Pure Cu2ZnSnO4 was found to have the lowest heat of formation, followed by Cu2ZnSnS4, and finally Cu2ZnSnSe4. This suggests that oxidization is very likely to occur, whereas selenization can only be accomplished under high temp. For the alloys, the energetically favorable chalcogen configurations are very different for oxygen and selenium. While the energies of the Se alloys are insensitive to the distribution of S and Se configurations, the lowest energy O alloys have alternating S and O sites in the a-b planes. In considering the heats of formation of the Cu2ZnSnSxO4-x alloys, we find that they are unstable with respect to decompn. into binary oxides and sulfides except for small concns. of O. Our results also show that it is energetically more favorable to sulfurize Cu2ZnSnSe4 than to selenize Cu2ZnSnS4. (c) 2014 American Institute of Physics.

Quantitative determination of optical and recombination losses in thin-film photovoltaic devices based on external quantum efficiency analysis
Nakane, Akihiro; Tampo, Hitoshi; Tamakoshi, Masato; Fujimoto, Shohei; Kim, Kang Min; Kim, Shinho; Shibata, Hajime; Niki, Shigeru; Fujiwara, Hiroyuki
Journal of Applied Physics (Melville, NY, United States)
(
2016
),
120
(
6
),
064505/1-064505/24
CODEN:
JAPIAU
; ISSN:
0021-8979
.
(
American Institute of Physics
)
In developing photovoltaic devices with high efficiencies, quant. detn. of the carrier loss is crucial. In conventional solar-cell characterization techniques, however, photocurrent redn. originating from parasitic light absorption and carrier recombination within the light absorber cannot be assessed easily. Here, we develop a general anal. scheme in which the optical and recombination losses in submicron-textured solar cells are evaluated systematically from external quantum efficiency (EQE) spectra. In this method, the optical absorption in solar cells is first deduced by imposing the anti-reflection condition in the calcn. of the absorptance spectrum, and the carrier extn. from the light absorber layer is then modeled by considering a carrier collection length from the absorber interface. Our anal. method is appropriate for a wide variety of photovoltaic devices, including kesterite solar cells [Cu2ZnSnSe4, Cu2ZnSnS4, and Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4], zincblende CdTe solar cells, and hybrid perovskite (CH3NH3PbI3) solar cells, and provides excellent fitting to numerous EQE spectra reported earlier. Based on the results obtained from our EQE analyses, we discuss the effects of parasitic absorption and carrier recombination in different types of solar cells. (c) 2016 American Institute of Physics.

Journal of Applied Physics (Melville, NY, United States)

We report measurement of minority carrier diffusion length (Ld) for high performance Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe) solar cells in comparison with analogous Cu(In,Ga)(S,Se)2 (CIGSSe) devices. Our Ld extn. method involves performing systematic measurements of the internal quantum efficiency combined with sep. capacitance-voltage measurement. This method also enables the measurement of the absorption coeff. of the absorber material as a function of wavelength in a finished device. The extd. values of Ld for CZTSSe samples are at least factor of 2 smaller than those for CIGSSe samples. Combined with minority carrier lifetime (Ï) data measured by time-resolved photoluminescence, we deduce the minority carrier mobility (Î¼e), which is also relatively low for the CZTSSe samples.

A review. Intense research has been carried out in the past few years to improve efficiencies and understand limitations in kesterite-based solar cells. Despite notable efforts to det. and list the different failure modes affecting the photovoltaic properties of these devices, very few works have tried to quantify and classify the effects of these failure modes. An exhaustive literature review has 1st been conducted to det. the different causes leading to limited efficiencies in kesterite devices, with an addnl. focus on Cd-free and crit. raw material-free devices. Second, an original approach has been employed to quantify the impact of these failure modes on solar cells, based on the evaluation of feedback from 18 scientific experts working on kesterite technol. The result of this survey is analyzed, which allows one to det. what should be the research priority for the community to improve efficiencies and drive kesterite technol. to the market.

We demonstrate the improved efficiency of a Cu2Zn(Sn1-xGex)Se4 (CZTGSe) thin-film solar cell with a conversion efficiency of 12.3%; this cell exhibits a greatly improved open-circuit voltage (VOC) deficit of 0.583V and a fill factor (FF) of 0.73 compared with previously reported CZTGSe cells. The VOC deficit was found to be improved through a reduced band tailing via the control of the Ge/(Sn + Se) ratio. In addn., the high FF was mainly induced by a reduced carrier recombination at the absorber/buffer interface and/or in the space charge region, whereas parasitic resistive effects on FF were very small.

Although Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe) has attracted attention as an alternative to CuInGaSe2 (CIGS) as an absorber material in solar cells, its low efficiency is a serious shortcoming preventing its commercialization. To realize a high-efficiency CZTSSe solar cell, improved grain crystallinity, inhibited secondary-phase formation, controlled defect generation, adequate Na content, and band gap grading are required in the absorber layer. Few studies have focused specifically on band gap grading. In this study, a method of using SeS2, a new potential chalcogenization source material, to control the S and Se contents in a CZTSSe absorber and its effects were investigated. Using an appropriate SeS2/Se wt. ratio, band gap grading was realized within the depletion region. By increasing the value of VOC through band gap grading in the depletion region, a record VOC deficit of 0.576 V was achieved. Furthermore, the possibility of enhancing JSC through the formation of a type-inverted n-type phase at the absorber surface in response to an appropriate alignment of the conduction-band min. energy level and the Fermi energy pinning level is discussed. By introducing the chalcogenization source material SeS2 during the annealing process, CZTSSe solar cells with a max. efficiency of 12.3% were obtained.

The effect of the band-gap profile on the performance of Cu2ZnSn(Sx,Se1-x)4 (CZTSSe) solar cells was investigated using a solar cell capacitance simulator (SCAPS) device simulation program. The band gap of CZTSSe is tunable from 1.0 to 1.5 eV by changing the S/(S + Se) ratio. Currently, the evolution of the electron affinity (Î§) of CZTSSe at various band gaps has not been clarified yet, although two models with different Î§ values at various band gaps of CZTSSe have been proposed. We simulated solar cell performance using these two models and the differential rates of efficiency were compared between them. As a result, we were able to design the optimum band-gap profile using both models. Meanwhile, the characteristics of a solar cell with various optical absorption coeffs. and defect densities of the CZTSSe absorber were simulated. The superiority of the graded band-gap profile was demonstrated by comparing the cell performances with and without a grading profile structure.

In this work we report on the effect of alkali doping via Na and/or K introduction into flexible and light-wt. Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) solar cells obtained using a sequential process based on the sputtering of metallic stacks and further reactive annealing. Different thicknesses of Cr diffusion barriers and 50 Î¼m thick ferritic steel substrates were used. We compare different doping methods: Na-doped Mo targets (MoNa), SLG underneath the flexible substrates, NaF and KF pre-absorber synthesis evapn. (PAS) and post-deposition evapn. (PDT). Addnl., we report on the importance of the Cr barrier and back contact modification to improve solar cell performance. A remarkable enhancement in the absorber grain size and surface morphol. occurred esp. when using Na via MoNa and PAS. Nevertheless, preliminary expts. led to better results for MoNa doping due to a higher Na content confirmed by TOF-SIMS. K doping via PAS also showed promising results. An increase in the efficiency of solar cells from 2.2% to 4.3% was possible when using a MoNa layer sandwiched between regular Mo layers. The improvement is mainly related to a higher VOC and FF. After performing a detailed Cr and back contact optimization, a record value of 6.1% for flexible CZTSe solar cells was recently obtained using MoNa and a new surface Ge doping.

Cu2SnZn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe) solar cells based on earth abundant and nontoxic elements currently achieve efficiencies exceeding 12%. It has been reported that, to obtain high efficiency devices, a post thermal treatment of absorbers or devices at temps. ranging between 150 and 400 Â°C (post low temp. treatment, PLTT) is advisable. Recent findings point toward a beneficial passivation of grain boundaries with SnOx or Cu-depleted surface and grain boundaries during the PLTT process, but no investigation regarding alkali doping is available, even though alkali dynamics, esp. Na, are systematically reported to be crucial within the field. In this work, CZTSSe absorbers were subjected to the PLTT process under different temps., and solar cells were completed. We found surprisingly behavior in which efficiency decreased to nearly 0% at 200 Â°C during the PLTT process, being recovered or even improved at temps. above 300 Â°C. This unusual behavior correlates well with the Na dynamics in the devices, esp. with the in-depth distribution of Na in the active CZTSSe/CdS interface region, indicating the key importance of Na spatial distribution on device properties. We present an innovative model for Na dynamics supported by theor. calcns. and addnl. specially designed expts. to explain this behavior. After optimization of the PLTT process, a Se-rich CZTSSe solar cell with 8.3% efficiency was achieved.

The effect of Na incorporation in Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) solar cells grown by the coevaporation method was investigated via photoluminescence (PL) and time-resolved PL (TRPL) measurements as well as photovoltaic properties. The TRPL decay curves showed a monotonic increase in CZTSe lifetime from 2 to 15 ns with increasing Na incorporation, which corresponds to the increase in the correction length estd. by quantum efficiency measurements. The TRPL decay curves included two decay components, fast and slow, which were discussed and concluded as originating from the recombination at the surface and bulk of CZTSe, resp., which is also supported by TPRL measurements with various excitation wavelengths. The lifetime of CZTSe is limited by the surface-related nonradiative recombination compared to Cu(In,Ga)Se2 devices which are fabricated with the same device structure except for the absorber, and at present, it is concluded that the surface recombination of the CZTSe limits the cell performance. In addn. to the above investigations, the relationship between the CZTSe bulk lifetime and carrier concn. is discussed; deep nonradiative recombination centers in the CZTSe bulk were found to decrease by one order of magnitude with Na incorporation. The Na incorporation primarily resulted in improvement in the short circuit c.d. and fill factor and not in the open circuit voltage, and the results are discussed. The best performing CZTSe solar cell with Na incorporation showed a conversion efficiency of 9.57%. (c) 2017 American Institute of Physics.

It is well established that the addn. of sodium (Na) to chalcopyrite or kesterite based solar cells markedly increases the solar cell performance. In this work, we explore the effect of Na and other alkali metals like potassium (K), rubidium, cesium and lithium (Li) - on pure selenide Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) solar cells. We demonstrate the deposition of alkali metals using spin coating on e-beam evapd. metal precursors. The stack of metal precursors with alkali layer was then selenized at high temps. to obtain a good quality CZTSe absorber. The diffusion of alkali metals into the absorber layer was confirmed using glow discharge optical emission spectroscopy. Samples doped with Na or K have shown improvement in the open circuit voltage. A max. power conversion efficiency of 8.3% (without anti-reflection coating) and a top open circuit voltage 430 mV was achieved for combination of K and Na. Amongst the rest of alkali metals, Li looks the most promising dopant as far as optoelectronic properties are concerned.

Potassium (K) post-treatment on CIGSSe has been shown to yield the highest efficiency reported to date. However, very little is known on the effect of K doping in CZTSSe and the mechanism behind the efficiency improvement. Here we reveal the mechanism by which K enhances the charge sepn. in CZTSSe. We show that K accumulates at the CdS/CZTSSe, passivating the recombination at the front interface and improving carrier collection. K is also found to accumulate at the CZTSSe/Mo interface and facilitates the diffusion of Cd into the absorber which affects the morphol. and grain growth of CZTSSe. As revealed by the C-V, external quantum efficiency, and color J-V test, K doping significantly increases the carrier d., improves carrier collection, and passivates the front interface and grain boundaries, leading to the enhancement of Voc and Jsc. The av. power conversion efficiency has been promoted from 5% to above 7%, and the best 7.78% efficiency has been achieved for the 1.5 mol % K-doped CZTSSe device. This work offers some new insights into the K doping effects on CZTSSe via soln.-based approach and demonstrates the potential of facile control of K doping for further improvement of CZTSSe thin film solar cells.

Sulfide kesterite Cu2ZnSnS4 provides an attractive low-cost, environmentally benign and stable photovoltaic material, yet the record power conversion efficiency for such solar cells has been stagnant at around 9% for years. Severe non-radiative recombination within the heterojunction region is a major cause limiting voltage output and overall performance. Here we report a certified 11% efficiency Cu2ZnSnS4 solar cell with a high 730 mV open-circuit voltage using heat treatment to reduce heterojunction recombination. This heat treatment facilitates elemental inter-diffusion, directly inducing Cd atoms to occupy Zn or Cu lattice sites, and promotes Na accumulation accompanied by local Cu deficiency within the heterojunction region. Consequently, new phases are formed near the hetero-interface and more favorable conduction band alignment is obtained, contributing to reduced non-radiative recombination. Using this approach, we also demonstrate a certified centimetre-scale (1.11 cm2) 10% efficiency Cu2ZnSnS4 photovoltaic device; the first kesterite cell (including selenium-contg.) of std. centimetre-size to exceed 10%.

ZnSe Etching of Zn-Rich Cu2ZnSnSe4: An Oxidation Route for Improved Solar-Cell Efficiency
Lopez-Marino, Simon; Sanchez, Yudania; Placidi, Marcel; Fairbrother, Andrew; Espindola-Rodriguez, Moises; Fontane, Xavier; Izquierdo-Roca, Victor; Lopez-Garcia, Juan; Calvo-Barrio, Lorenzo; Perez-Rodriguez, Alejandro; Saucedo, Edgardo

Cu2ZnSnSe4 kesterite-type compds. are some of the most promising materials for low-cost thin-film photovoltaics. However, the synthesis of absorbers for high-performing devices is still a complex issue. So far, the best devices rely on absorbers grown in a Zn-rich and Cu-poor environment. These off-stoichiometric conditions favor the presence of a ZnSe secondary phase, which has been proved to be highly detrimental for device performance. Therefore, an effective method for the selective removal of this phase is important. Previous attempts to remove this phase by using acidic etching or highly toxic org. compds. have been reported but so far with moderate impact on device performance. Herein, a new oxidizing route to ensure efficient removal of ZnSe is presented based on treatment with a mixt. of an oxidizing agent and a mineral acid followed by treatment in an aq. Na2S soln. Three different oxidizing agents were tested: H2O2, KMnO4, and K2Cr2O7, combined with different concns. of H2SO4. With all of these agents Se2- from the ZnSe surface phase is selectively oxidized to Se0, forming an elemental Se phase, which is removed with the subsequent etching in Na2S. Using KMnO4 in a H2SO4-based medium, a large improvement on the conversion efficiency of the devices is obsd., related to an improvement of all the optoelectronic parameters of the cells. Improvement of short-circuit c.d. (Jsc) and series resistance is directly related to the selective etching of the ZnSe surface phase, which has a demonstrated current-blocking effect. In addn., a significant improvement of open-circuit voltage (Voc), shunt resistance (Rsh), and fill factor (FF) are attributed to a passivation effect of the kesterite absorber surface resulting from the chem. processes, an effect that likely leads to a redn. of nonradiative-recombination states d. and a subsequent improvement of the p-n junction.

Time-resolved luminescence (TRL) is a nondestructive, noninvasive, and contactless characterization method. The authors studied TRL decay on semiconductor layers and thin film homostructures after a steady state illumination by simulation with Synopsys TCAD and by anal. approx. soln. of the appropriate equations. First, the luminescence decay time in general is the minority carrier lifetime only for a homogeneous and time-independent carrier lifetime. Then, the authors study the influence of photon recycling, injection level, charge carrier diffusion, defects in the bulk and at the surfaces, as well as space charge on the TRL decay sep. by quasi 1-dimensional simulations of semiconductor layers and semiconductor homostructures. The authors further study the influence of sample nonhomogeneity as may be found in polycryst. semiconductors. Carrier lifetime can be extd. from the TRL transients and the samples can be characterized by excitation dependent measurements in the open circuit case. The authors can explain some effects found in luminescence expts., like a decrease of the decay time with an increasing excitation, a max. in the decay time due to satd. bulk-defects and curved luminescence transients due to high injections or sample inhomogeneities. Also, the authors are focussing on the question, how single layers within a semiconductor stack can be characterized. (c) 2014 American Institute of Physics.

We present a device characterization study for hydrazine-processed kesterite Cu2ZnSn(Se,S)4 (CZTSSe) solar cells with a focus on pinpointing the main loss mechanisms limiting device efficiency. Temp.-dependent study and time-resolved photoluminescence spectroscopy on these cells, in comparison to analogous studies on a ref. Cu(In,Ga)(Se,S)2 (CIGS) cell, reveal strong recombination loss at the CZTSSe/CdS interface, very low minority-carrier lifetimes, and high series resistance that diverges at low temp. These findings help identify the key areas for improvement of these CZTSSe cells in the quest for a high-performance indium- and tellurium-free solar cell. (c) 2010 American Institute of Physics.

In this work, the benefits of Ag-alloying in kesterite solar cells are explored in terms of tunable band gap, improved grain growth, improved minority carrier lifetime, reduced defect formation, and reduced potential fluctuations for (Ag,Cu)2ZnSnSe4 (ACZTSe) absorbers relative to Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe). The enhanced optoelectronic properties are shown to scale here with the degree of Ag-alloying in ACZTSe. The impacts of these effects on device performance are discussed, with improvement in av. device performance/open-circuit voltage reported for ACZTSe (5%-Ag) absorbers relative to CZTSe absorbers with similar band gap. These initial results are promising for the Ag-alloyed ACZTSe material system as VOC limitations are the primary cause of poor device performance in kesterite solar cells, and cation substitution presents a unique method to tune the defect properties of kesterite absorbers. Herein, nanoparticle synthesis and large-grain ACZTSe absorber formation is described followed by material and optoelectronic characterization. Addnl., RTP processing is presented to achieve fully selenized large-grain chalcogenide absorbers from sulfide nanocrystal inks.

It is a challenge to fabricate high quality Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) film with low Cu content (Cu/(Zn + Sn) < 0.8). In this work, the growth mechanisms of CZTSe films under different Se vapor compn. are investigated by DC-sputtering and a postselenization approach. The compn. of Se vapor has important effect on the compactability of the films and the diffusion of elements in the CZTSe films. By adjusting the compn. of Se vapor during the selenization process, an optimized two step selenization process is proposed and highly crystd. CZTSe film with low Cu content (Cu/(Zn + Sn) = 0.75) is obtained. Further study of the effect of Cu content on the morphol. and photovoltaic performance of the corresponding CZTSe solar cells has shown that the roughness of the CZTSe absorber film increases when Cu content decreases. As a consequence, the reflection loss of CZTSe solar cells reduces dramatically and the short circuit c.d. of the cells improve from 34.7 mA/cm2 for Cu/(Zn + Sn) = 0.88 to 38.5 mA/cm2 for Cu/(Zn + Sn) = 0.75. In addn., the CZTSe solar cells with low Cu content show longer minority carrier lifetime and higher open circuit voltage than the high Cu content devices. A champion performance CZTSe solar cell with 10.4% efficiency is fabricated with Cu/(Zn + Sn) = 0.75 in the CZTSe film without antireflection coating.

With the aim of exploring oxidn. and selenization of the photovoltaic material Cu2ZnSnS4, we used first principles methods to study the structure and stability of Cu2ZnSnSxO4-x and Cu2ZnSnSxSe4-x alloys for 0 â¤ x â¤ 4. Pure Cu2ZnSnO4 was found to have the lowest heat of formation, followed by Cu2ZnSnS4, and finally Cu2ZnSnSe4. This suggests that oxidization is very likely to occur, whereas selenization can only be accomplished under high temp. For the alloys, the energetically favorable chalcogen configurations are very different for oxygen and selenium. While the energies of the Se alloys are insensitive to the distribution of S and Se configurations, the lowest energy O alloys have alternating S and O sites in the a-b planes. In considering the heats of formation of the Cu2ZnSnSxO4-x alloys, we find that they are unstable with respect to decompn. into binary oxides and sulfides except for small concns. of O. Our results also show that it is energetically more favorable to sulfurize Cu2ZnSnSe4 than to selenize Cu2ZnSnS4. (c) 2014 American Institute of Physics.

Quantitative determination of optical and recombination losses in thin-film photovoltaic devices based on external quantum efficiency analysis
Nakane, Akihiro; Tampo, Hitoshi; Tamakoshi, Masato; Fujimoto, Shohei; Kim, Kang Min; Kim, Shinho; Shibata, Hajime; Niki, Shigeru; Fujiwara, Hiroyuki

In developing photovoltaic devices with high efficiencies, quant. detn. of the carrier loss is crucial. In conventional solar-cell characterization techniques, however, photocurrent redn. originating from parasitic light absorption and carrier recombination within the light absorber cannot be assessed easily. Here, we develop a general anal. scheme in which the optical and recombination losses in submicron-textured solar cells are evaluated systematically from external quantum efficiency (EQE) spectra. In this method, the optical absorption in solar cells is first deduced by imposing the anti-reflection condition in the calcn. of the absorptance spectrum, and the carrier extn. from the light absorber layer is then modeled by considering a carrier collection length from the absorber interface. Our anal. method is appropriate for a wide variety of photovoltaic devices, including kesterite solar cells [Cu2ZnSnSe4, Cu2ZnSnS4, and Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4], zincblende CdTe solar cells, and hybrid perovskite (CH3NH3PbI3) solar cells, and provides excellent fitting to numerous EQE spectra reported earlier. Based on the results obtained from our EQE analyses, we discuss the effects of parasitic absorption and carrier recombination in different types of solar cells. (c) 2016 American Institute of Physics.

This communication studies the pure selenide phase CZTSe thin film solar cells prepd. by vacuum evapn. and demonstrates a power conversion efficiency of 11.6%, which is the highest certified efficiency among CZTSe-based thin-film solar cells reported to date. Device characterization indicate that the higher efficiencies appear to be related to significantly enhanced tranport properties for photogenerated carriers.

Minority carrier diffusion length extraction in Cu2ZnSn(Se,S)4 solar cells
Gokmen, Tayfun; Gunawan, Oki; Mitzi, David B.
Journal of Applied Physics (Melville, NY, United States)

0021-8979

(
American Institute of Physics
)
We report measurement of minority carrier diffusion length (Ld) for high performance Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe) solar cells in comparison with analogous Cu(In,Ga)(S,Se)2 (CIGSSe) devices. Our Ld extn. method involves performing systematic measurements of the internal quantum efficiency combined with sep. capacitance-voltage measurement. This method also enables the measurement of the absorption coeff. of the absorber material as a function of wavelength in a finished device. The extd. values of Ld for CZTSSe samples are at least factor of 2 smaller than those for CIGSSe samples. Combined with minority carrier lifetime (Ï) data measured by time-resolved photoluminescence, we deduce the minority carrier mobility (Î¼e), which is also relatively low for the CZTSSe samples.
